I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the 2012 country programming review mission, the Government of the People’s 
Republic of China (PRC), through the Ministry of Environmental Protection (MEP), requested 
policy and advisory technical assistance (TA) from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to help 
improve the policy and management system for rural environmental protection. The TA was 
included in the PRC country operations business plan, 2013–2015.1 A reconnaissance mission 
was  conducted  during  23–28  May  2013.  During  the  mission  and  subsequent  discussions, 
understandings  and  agreement  were  reached  on  the  project  impact,  outcome,  outputs, 
implementation  arrangements,  cost,  financing  arrangements,  and  terms  of  reference  for 
consulting  services,  as  recorded  in  a  memorandum  of  understanding.  The  design  and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Environmental degradation in rural areas of the PRC, which undermines the sustainable 
development of rural areas, has become a pressing issue. Pollution of surface water has been 
particularly serious, resulting in a large percentage of the rural population being forced to rely on 
unsafe sources for drinking water. Because of their limited access to centralized water supply 
systems, rural residents are highly vulnerable to the health hazards of water pollution. Of the 
409 sections of major rivers where water quality is monitored, 40.0% were found to have water 
quality that was unsafe for human consumption and 16.4% had water quality that was unsafe for 
any use.3 Major sources of water pollution in rural areas include agricultural runoff, untreated 
sewage, industrial and household solid waste, and livestock discharges from intensive animal 
husbandry enterprises. In most small towns and villages, there are virtually no pollution control 
measures to deal with sewage and animal waste. As a result, large quantities of untreated 
waste are discharged into the environment.   
 
3.  Recognizing the serious status of the rural environment, the government has issued a 
number  of  policy  guidance  documents  and  devoted  significant  resources  to  deal  with  the 
challenges. Under the Promoting Treatment through Incentives Program launched in 2008, the 
central government established special funds to supplement local government resources for 
implementing  rural  environmental  improvement  projects.  The  government  is  committed  to 
improving the rural environment, as reflected in the 12th Five-Year Plan. Protecting drinking 
water sources is a key government priority, which contributes to reduced rural–urban disparities 
and  improved  rural  livelihoods.  The  plan  emphasizes  strengthening  of  monitoring  and 
enforcement  of  water  quality  measures  and  raising  public  awareness.  It  also  addresses 
centralized treatment of sewage and solid waste from rural areas near urban centers, and 
adoption of appropriate low-cost, low-maintenance technologies for small-scale treatment in 
remote rural areas. 
 
4.  Although the government has made some progress in improving the rural environment, 
the challenges are daunting. Rural households are distributed over large geographical areas, 
making it difficult to achieve economies of scale in collection and treatment. Waste management

costs  would  be  prohibitively  high  if  measures  were  patterned  on  urban  approaches.  The 
widening gap in economic development between rural and urban areas has resulted in very 
limited availability of resources in rural areas for investing in the infrastructure required to treat 
sewage  and  solid  wastes.  Further,  it  is  unlikely  that  user fees  could finance  the required 
infrastructure, as rural households are relatively poor. Similarly, institutional capacity in rural 
areas for environmental monitoring and enforcement is weak. Public attitudes and individual 
behavior of the rural population are also contributing factors to environmental deterioration. 
Littering  and  dumping  of  household  garbage  is  prevalent,  which  further  aggravates 
environmental problems in rural areas and reduces the effectiveness of measures to collect 
garbage for centralized treatment. 
 
5.  To deal with these challenges, the government has requested that ADB provide TA to (i) 
review the current status of sewage and household solid-waste management in rural areas of 
the  PRC; (ii)  examine experiences  and  evidence  accumulated  in  developed  countries;  (iii) 
analyze the feasibility and effectiveness of, and constraints on, various approaches to sewage 
and household solid-waste management in the PRC context, and recommend policy options 
and  programs  with  regard  to  the  above  findings;  and  (iv)  prepare  a  knowledge  product 
summarizing the findings.     
 
6.  ADB has supported two TA projects—in 2002 and 2011—to help the MEP develop 
regulations on rural pollution prevention. The two TA projects focused on nonpoint source 
pollution  from  agricultural  and  animal  husbandry  sources,  and  included  development  of  a 
pollution management framework and medium-term action plans for addressing rural nonpoint 
source pollution.4 In addition, ADB has supported a number of TA projects—e.g., in Anhui and 
Guangdong  provinces—to  help  formulate  provincial  development  strategies  for  rural 
environmental protection and to develop waste management capacity in small cities and towns 
that  include  service  for  nearby  rural  areas.5 The  TA  will  build  on  and  contribute  to  the 
achievements of past and ongoing TA projects and focus on the management of sewage and 
household solid waste in support of the MEP’s efforts to improve the rural environment.   
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The  impact  of  the  TA  is  an  improved  policy  and  regulatory  framework  for  rural 
environmental protection infrastructure in the PRC. The outcome of the TA will be an improved 
management framework for sewage and household solid-waste management in rural areas.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  The TA will focus on addressing aspects of the management framework for sewage and 
solid-waste treatment that can benefit from adoption of international experiences and best 
practices. The review of international experience and best practices will follow a case study

approach, which allows the study design, procedures, and types of analyses to be determined 
based on the strengths of different management systems. 
 
9.  Output  1:  A  background  review  of  the  current  status  of  rural  sewage  and 
household solid-waste management in the People’s Republic of China conducted. The 
review will (i) focus on summarizing current technologies, policies, institutional arrangements, 
incentive frameworks, and financing and public awareness measures; and (ii) identify areas 
where improvement is needed. 
 
10.  Output 2: A review of international experiences in rural sewage and household 
solid-waste management conducted. The review will include experiences and in-depth case 
studies of rural sewage and household solid-waste management in Japan; the Republic of 
Korea; Taipei,China; the United States; and Germany. A summary of international experience 
and best practices in the following areas will be prepared under each case study: 
(i)  key technological choices for applications targeting different settlement patterns, 
waste composition, and treatment levels;  
(ii)  mechanisms  for  constructing,  operating,  and  maintaining  rural  environmental 
infrastructure,  including  institutional  arrangements  and  supporting  legal  and 
policy frameworks;  
(iii)  financing arrangements and supporting policy and legal frameworks, including 
fiscal transfers, subsidies, payment for ecosystem services, waste management 
funds and bonds, and public–private partnerships;  
(iv)  policy and institutional arrangements for monitoring and enforcing rural water 
environment provisions, particularly with regard to drinking water sources; and  
(v)  public  awareness  and  community  and  civil  society  participation  programs  to 
promote desirable behavioral changes.  
 
11.  Output 3: Policy recommendations for improving rural sewage and household 
solid-waste  management  in  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  prepared.  International 
experience and best practices will be analyzed, focusing on appropriateness in the PRC context, 
and policy recommendations will be prepared on (i) technical solution options; (ii) financing and 
operation and management arrangements; and (iii) supporting regulatory and legal frameworks, 
public  awareness,  community,  and  civil  society  participation  programs.  Public  awareness, 
community, and civil society participation programs will be designed for implementation on a 
pilot basis under the government’s broader program to improve the rural environment. 
 
12.  Output 4: A knowledge product prepared. The knowledge product will summarize the 
case studies and key policy recommendations.  
 
13.  The  major  assumptions  considered  include  that  (i)  the  government  will  continue  to 
support rural environmental improvement, particularly sewage and solid-waste treatment; (ii) 
adequate local counterpart support is provided for the operation and maintenance of wastewater 
and solid-waste management systems; and (iii) international experiences and lessons on rural 
environmental protection can be applied to the PRC’s institutional and socioeconomic context, 
after  modifications.  The  risks  to  be  mitigated  are  the  difficulty  anticipated  in  cross-sector 
coordination of government departments involved in rural environmental management, and in 
reaching consensus on an integrated management framework.

4   
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $600,000, of which $450,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources) and $100,000 on a 
grant basis by the Multi-Donor Trust Fund6 under the Water Financing Partnership Facility, and 
administered  by  ADB.  The  government  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of 
remuneration and per diems for counterpart staff (including time and travel expenses), logistical 
support  in  arrangement  of  workshops  and  conferences,  a  fully  functional  office  space  for 
consultants with free water and utility supply and free access to the internet and a photocopying 
machine, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The MEP will be the executing agency. A TA consultative committee will be established 
to  provide  guidance  on  project  implementation.  The  committee  will  be  led  by  the  MEP’s 
Department of Ecology. This committee will comprise the deputy director general, a director and 
a deputy director of the Department of Ecology, and a director of the Project Management 
Division 1 of the Foreign Economic Cooperation Office (FECO) of the MEP. FECO will be the 
implementing agency, and a TA management office will be established in FECO to carry out 
day-to-day TA operations. The director of the Project Management Division 1 of FECO will 
serve as the executive director of the TA management office responsible for coordinating day-
to-day operational matters among ADB, consultants, and related government agencies.  
 
16.  The TA will be implemented over a period of 16 months, from 1 December 2013 to 31 
March 2015. A consulting firm will be engaged to assist ADB and the executing agency in 
implementing the TA. The firm will provide a total of 26 person-months of consulting services, 
which will involve three international consultants (for a total of 10 person-months) and three 
national consultants (for a total of 16 person-months). The consultants will be engaged following 
ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time), using the 
quality- and cost-based selection method, with a quality–cost ratio of 80:20. The simplified 
technical proposal approach will be used to assess the qualifications of the bidding firms. The 
government requested advance contracting to ensure that consultants will be mobilized on time. 
The TA funds will be disbursed following ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook 
(2010, as amended from time to time).  
 
17.  The TA results  will  be  disseminated through reports,  workshops,  and  a knowledge 
product. The knowledge product will be developed and disseminated in hard copies by ADB, the 
PRC Resident Mission, and the MEP, and will be posted on the ADB website.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $100,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Multi-Donor Trust Fund under the Water Financing Partnership 
Facility, and (ii) ADB providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of $450,000 on a grant 
basis to the Government of the People’s Republic of China for the Policy and Management 
System Development for Rural Environmental Protection, and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Introduction 
1.   The consultants will be engaged by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) through a firm 
following ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time) 
using the quality- and cost-based selection method, with a quality–cost ratio of 80:20. It is 
estimated that the technical assistance (TA) will require three international consultants (for a 
total of 10 person-months) and three national consultants (for a total of 16 person-months). The 
international consultants comprise an environment specialist and team leader, rural sewage and 
solid-waste  management  specialist,  and  a  communications  and  behavioral  interventions 
specialist. The national consultants comprise an environmental policy specialist and deputy 
team leader, rural sanitation specialist, and environmental engineer. 
 
B.  International Consultants 
1.  Environment Specialist and Team Leader (international, 5 person-months) 
 
2.  The environment specialist and team leader should have a post-graduate degree or 
equivalent and 15 or more years of experience in relevant fields. Demonstrated project-related 
experience  in  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  is  desirable.  The  specialist  will  be 
responsible for the final outputs of the study and the daily coordination and supervision of the 
TA team. Specifically, the specialist will undertake the following tasks:  
(i)  develop the detailed study framework in consultation with the executing agency, 
key stakeholders, and other experts;  
(ii)  develop outlines of the inception, interim, and final TA reports;  
(iii)  compile and finalize the TA reports, including the inception, interim, and final 
reports, and their revised versions;  
(iv)  manage and ensure timely implementation of TA activities, including the overall 
coordination of inputs from team members, and conduct inception, interim, final, 
and dissemination workshops;  
(v)  organize workshops and study tours; 
(vi)  summarize  findings  and  lessons  learned from two  previous  related  ADB  TA 
projects on nonpoint source pollution;1 
(vii)  for the five countries selected for case studies, (a) review international practices 
and  experiences  in  financing  arrangements,  and  supporting  policy  and  legal 
frameworks, including fiscal transfers, subsidies, payment for ecosystem services 
(eco-compensation),  waste  management  funds  and  bonds,  public–private 
partnerships,  and  other  modalities;  (b)  review  international  practices  and 
experiences in operation and management arrangements, and supporting policy 
and  legal  frameworks;  and  (c)  compile  appendixes  for  the  literature  review, 
including  selected  original  texts  of  relevant  regulations,  legislation,  and 
agreements; 
(viii)  draft policy recommendations on the institutional and legal framework supporting 
the financing, operation, and management of rural wastewater and solid-waste 
treatment  facilities,  and  ensuring  feasibility  and  appropriateness  in  the  PRC 
context; and

2.  Rural  Sewage  and  Solid-Waste  Management  Specialist  (international,  3

3.  The rural sewage and solid-waste management specialist should have a post-graduate 
degree or equivalent and 15 or more years of experience in relevant fields. Demonstrated 
project-related experience in the PRC is desirable. The specialist will undertake the following 
tasks: 
(i)  provide substantial inputs into the development and refining of a study framework 
and outlines of TA reports;  
(ii)  participate in and present relevant topics during project seminars and workshops;  
(iii)  for the countries selected for case studies, review international practices and 
summarize and categorize 
(a)  the technologies by treatment technology type (e.g., primary, secondary, 
advanced) and by output treatment quality fit for discharging, and various 
reuse or recycle applications; and 
(b)  differences in approaches to urban- and rural-generated waste; methods 
of waste selection, collection, storage, transfer, processing, and disposal; 
enforcement  of  collection,  disposal,  and  composting  standards; 
enforcement of environmental codes; monitoring systems; and programs 
on waste reduction, recycling, and composting; 
(iv)  collaborate with the national consultants and, under the team leader’s guidance, 
develop a technical guide summarizing technological options for rural sewage 
and household solid-waste management, focusing on economic and financial 
viability and appropriateness for local conditions; 
(v)  provide inputs into TA reports, including inception, interim, and final reports, and 
their revised versions; and  
(vi)  summarize the findings of the TA in a knowledge product. 
 
3.  Communications  and  Behavioral  Interventions  Specialist  (international,  2 
person-months) 
 
4.  The  communications  and  behavioral  interventions  specialist  should  have  a  post-

3.  Environmental Engineer (national, 5 person-months) 
 
7.  The environmental engineer should have a post-graduate degree or equivalent and 10
